#Text=Blue Lake Provincial Park
#Text=Blue Lake Provincial Park is a 2314-ha recreational park in Northern Ontario , Canada .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The park is open mid-May to Mid-September .
#Text=Barrier-free access is available at both comfort stations .
#Text=There is also a wheelchair ramp at the day-use area .
#Text=Each of the park ’s campgrounds has a comfort station with showers and flush toilets .
#Text=The 1-km beach at Blue Lake is a popular day-use area .
#Text=This sandy beach has buoyed swimming areas and shady areas with picnic tables , water taps and hibachis .
#Text=Flush toilets are found in various locations throughout the campground and day-use area .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Take Highway 17 ( the Trans-Canada Highway ) to Vermilion Bay ( west of Dryden ) , then turn north onto Highway 647 ( Blue Lake Rd ) and travel 10 km .
#Text=Fees and permits
#Text=Daily vehicle
#Text=permit :
#Text=Regular $ 11 - 20
#Text=Ontario Senior $ 9.00 - 16
#Text=Ontarian with Disabilities $ 5.50 - 10
#Text=See
#Text=The Visitor Centre , in an old log cabin at the south end of the beach , has displays of plant , rock and wildlife specimens .
#Text=The cabin is one of the original cottages from the early days of Blue Lake campers .
#Text=Hiking
#Text=There are hiking trails ranging from easy , interpretive trails to longer day hikes .
#Text=Boulder Ridge Trail – 1 km , easy , 30 minutes .
#Text=Walk through a forest created by fire , onto a ridge made by ice and over sands carried by rivers now dry .
#Text=Goblin Lake Trail – 11 km , moderate , full day .
#Text=It follows the edge of Goblin Lake and explores the wilds of Northern Ontario the way pioneers would have .
#Text=Rock Point Trail – 4 km , moderate .
#Text=This trail takes you through a variety of environments from cedar groves to Jack Pine ridges .
#Text=Varying terrain : be sure to wear appropriate foot wear .
#Text=It starts at the beaver pond and loops back to the campground near M road .
#Text=Spruce Fen Boardwalk Trail - 1 km , easy , barrier-free , 30 minutes
#Text=In a fen , land floats on water , plants eat animals and creatures of the water fly .
#Text=The Spruce Fen Trail takes you through a Black Spruce fen and a beaver pond environment .
#Text=Interpretive signs help describe these environments along the trail .
#Text=To protect the fen , the trail is a boardwalk and is also wheelchair accessible .
#Text=Canoeing
#Text=Route 12
#Text=Blue Lake
#Text=– 97 km loop , partially in the park , moderate , 5-7 days .
#Text=This route features varied scenery , wildlife and sandy beaches .
#Text=In the past , portages were used as trading routes to the Hudson Bay Post on Eagle Lake .
#Text=There is also an abandoned Mica mine site on Cobble Lake .
#Text=Detailed maps and more canoe route information is available at the Blue Lake Park Office .
#Text=Canoes and kayaks are available for rent .
#Text=Personal Floatation Devices ( life jackets ) are also available on loan with a $ 25 refundable deposit .
#Text=Birding
#Text=The boreal forest is home to a variety of bird species .
#Text=Often the Common Loon fills the evening sky with its mournful song as Chimney Swifts fly high above , snagging insects out of the air .
#Text=Bald Eagles are common place as well as many forest dwelling song birds .
#Text=Bird checklists are available at the Visitor Centre .
#Text=Boating
#Text=Power boats are allowed on all lakes within the park .
#Text=Be aware of non-motorized canoes , kayaks and sailboats .
#Text=There is a boat launch at the north end of the beach and a dock is available .
#Text=Buy
#Text=There is a Park Store in the main entry station that sells basic camper needs and Ontario Parks ’ merchandise .
#Text=The store features clothing items , souvenirs , books and ice cream .
#Text=Thrre are coin-operated washers and dryers in both of Blue Lakes ’ comfort stations .
#Text=Eat and drink
#Text=Ice and groceries are available outside of the park in Vermilion Bay , nine km south of the park on Highway 17 .
#Text=Lodging
#Text=There is a travel trailer available with dinette , couch slide , screened-in add-a-room , cook stove , fridge , air conditioner , heater , shower and two sinks with potable water .
#Text=There is no toilet , but a vault toilet is available nearby .
#Text=Reserve online .
#Text=Camping
#Text=There is a range of car camping opportunities from private tent pads to pull through sites with parking areas .
#Text=Half of the campsites offer electrical hook-up .
#Text=Amenities such as water taps , comfort stations and laundry facilities are close by .
#Text=Swimming , boating and the Visitor Centre are only a short distance away .
#Text=Two campsites are reserved for campers who require barrier-free access .

#Text=2018 rates per night per camping site : $ 41 - 51 for electrical sites ( $ 33 - 41 for Ontario seniors , $ 21 - 26 for Ontarians with disabilities ; $ 36 - 45 for non-electrical sites ( $ 29 - 36 for Ontario seniors , $ 18 - 23 for Ontarians with disabilities ) .
